subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: Actually, if you were really following TDD then you wouldn t have the private method unless it was already covered by tests.  At least that s the methodology I
messageBody:
Actually, if you were really following TDD then you wouldn't have the
private method unless it was already covered by tests. At least that's
the methodology I use (no change happens to my code until there's a
failing test forcing the change, except for refactoring). So the code
coverage tool shouldn't be (as) necessary. I've found I only use them
for those project where (someone else :) wrote the code without writing
tests first. In that case, it helps to know the coverage, but also can
give me a false sense of security.

..David..

Subject: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.


J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> JBR's postulate 1. For every testable design that requires exposing
> elements "just for testing", there exists an equivalent testable
> design that does not require exposing elements "just for testing".
>
> In other words, if I add a method "just for testing", I can usually
> find a way to restructure the design so that that method either
> earns its keep or goes away. I don't have a specific example right
> now, because whenever I see one, I don't have time to write about
> it.
>

Nice.

After thinking about it for awhile, here are some things I think could
be done (in order) before making private methods public for testing
when you are practicing TDD:

1. Use a code coverage tool to determine whether the method is
already being adequately covered by tests against the existing public
methods of the class. If so, stop worrying. You're done.
http://java-source.net/open-source/code-coverage

2. If test coverage is inadequate, determine whether unit tests
against the existing public methods can be added. Do it. Return to
step 1.

3. Determine whether Extract Class should be used to split the
responsibilities of the class into two or more abstractions. If so,
refactor and write unit tests for the public methods of the new
classes. Return to step 1.

4. Delete the code (OK! OK! -- just set the current implementation
aside) and reimplement the class using the existing unit tests.
Comment out all but one test and get to green. Do the simplest thing
that works. Only write code that is actually required to satisfy the
test. Refactor aggressively. Repeat.

Thoughts?

Regards,
Jim
